column1: Ham Lake is a city in Anoka County
column3: United States. It is a suburb in the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area. The population was 15

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 35.71 square miles (92.49 km2)
column4: 34.39 square miles (89.07 km2) is land and 1.32 square miles (3.42 km2) is water.Ham Lake is located in the central part of Anoka County.

column1: Oak Grove (northwest)The community of Soderville is located within the northern part of the city of Ham Lake.
Minnesota State Highway 65 serves as a main route in the city.
The earliest record of settlers in the Ham Lake area goes back to 1855
column3: the settlers established a town located just south and west of a lake shaped like a ham. The settlers platted and sold lots for a community they named Glen Carey
column4: a Scottish name meaning "beautiful valley". The location was widely advertised as a future city. However
column6: all of the houses were destroyed by a prairie fire.  Some of the inhabitants barely escaped with their lives saving only a very few household goods. The settlers soon left the area as they had nowhere to live.

column1: There was no more settlement until 1866
column2: when a Norwegian man settled in the area. He was soon followed by other Scandinavians. The Scandinavian settlers found it difficult to pronounce the Scottish name of Glen Carey. Since no official name had been chosen by the people
column3: the commissioners named it Ham Lake
column4: after the lake which had acquired that name on account of its shape.The early settlers found the soil well suited to farming as it was not as rocky as they had been accustomed to in Scandinavia. Through the years
column5: dairying became an important industry. The pioneer farmers soon found the soil well suited to growing potatoes and this became an important commodity for both cash sales and trading. Ham Lake Township would split from Grow Township (Andover) in 1871. From the early 1900s through the 1930s
column6: potato farming was at its peak in then named Ham Lake Township. Some of the farms remaining today are the sod farms in the southeast part of the city
column7: where the ground is low and the soil black and heavy making it well suited to this crop as well as corn and potatoes in some places.

column2: when the population was over 400 people
column3: a group of farmers joined together to form a cooperative and built a creamery. Several general stores were built there shortly afterwards. What became the main store in town
column5: was built on land sold to the Soderquist family by the Olson family
column6: who had extensive landholdings along what would later become Highway 65. Like many small American communities
column7: over time all the "old" families became related through marriage. Although many of the establishing families have since moved away from Ham Lake due to increasing property taxes and crowding
column9: and many members of the families are still in close contact.

column2: a service garage was opened in the northern part of Ham Lake.
with Eldon Hentges as the first Fire Chief.

column1: Ham Lake officially became a city on January 8
column3: with Eldon Hentges serving as the first Mayor.
